Those who braved the inclement

Hall heard speeches that were well
worth listening to. The meeting, called by a number of Baltimore citizens,
was presided over by Mr. Theodore
Marburg, who gave a brief survey
of the development of International
Arbitration, and of the results, tangible and intangible, which had been
arrived at by the two Hague Conferences. The first speaker was Dr.
James Brown Scott, Solicitor for the
Department of State and Professor of
International Law at the George
Washington University. During the
past two years Dr. Scott has lectured
at this university on international
law. He is the author of numerous
works, the most recent as well as
important of which is "The Hague
Peace Conferences of 1899 and 1907,"
published by the Johns Hopkins Press.
Dr. Scott was the first advocate of
International Court of Arbitral Justice, and through his efforts the American delegates to the Second Hague
Conference were instructed by Secretary of State Root to advocate the
adoption of such a tribunal. They
succeeded in having adopted by the
conference a convention embodying
their proposal. His address was devoted to an exposition of the theory
of this court, the stage of advancement in the pacific settlement of international disputes which it typifies,
and the normal evolution which made
it possible.

COUNTRY SCHOOL
EXPECTS TO MOVE
School now on Homewood Property Probably to Change Location Soon
The Country School for Boys, a
photograph of the main building of
which is herewith reproduced, expects
to move to Roland Park in the near
future. A desirable tract of land has
been secured at the southeast corner
of Roland and Belvedere Avenues,
about thirty-four acres of which will
be retained for the use of the school,
the rest probably to be disposed of
for building sites. About $74,000 has
already been secured, and it is probable that sufficient funds will soon
be forthcoming to allow removal to
more suitable quarters. Certificates
of Indebtedness are now being circulated for the purpose of collecting the
remainder of the fund. It is only
necessary to accumulate $26,000 in
addition to the money already subscribed in order for the school to
move. It is therefore expected that
.the building at Homewood may be
vacated by the opening of the University next year.
In front of the Carroll mansion,
which the University expects to keep
for use when Hopkins moves to
Homewood, there is a stretch of land
down to Charles street which will
probably form the future campus.
During the summer and fall work
has been carried on in grading this
land, though its condition is now an
eyesore, owing to the work not being
complete. The "campus," in fact, has
been graded so as to form a bowl,
with a driveway around that part of
the "rim" which is not bordered by
Charles street. No arrangement has
as yet been made for properly draining this land. It is thought by many
that a slope gradually rising from the
street up to the half-circle of future
buildings would be more attractive.
The Carroll Mansion will form one
of the half-circle of buildings which
will probably extend around the rim
of the bowl above referred to. It does
not require an optimistic imagination
to picture with ease a university campus surrounded by stately buildings of
the Colonial style, similar in architecture to the Carroll Mansion.
The intended move of the Country School will be of interest to many
Hopkins Alumni. Among graduates
of the University who have taught
there at various times are: Roland J.
Mulford (headmaster), S. Wardwell
Kinney (headmaster), N. H. Ballard,
Arthur Lamb, J. Howard Post, William Starr Myers, Arthur Baxter,
Robert B. Roulston, Thomas De C.
Ruh, Samuel C. Chew, Robert Campbell, Walter Clark Haupt, and Herbert Cannon Lipscomb.

COUNTRY SCHOOL
EXPECTS TO MOVE
School now on Homewood Property Probably to Change Location Soon
The Country School for Boys, a
photograph of the main building of
which is herewith reproduced, expects
to move to Roland Park in the near
future. A desirable tract of land has
been secured at the southeast corner
of Roland and Belvedere Avenues,
about thirty-four acres of which will
be retained for the use of the school,
the rest probably to be disposed of
for building sites. About $74,000 has
already been secured, and it is probable that sufficient funds will soon
be forthcoming to allow removal to
more suitable quarters. Certificates
of Indebtedness are now being circulated for the purpose of collecting the
remainder of the fund. It is only
necessary to accumulate $26,000 in
addition to the money already subscribed in order for the school to
move. It is therefore expected that
.the building at Homewood may be
vacated by the opening of the University next year.
In front of the Carroll mansion,
which the University expects to keep
for use when Hopkins moves to
Homewood, there is a stretch of land
down to Charles street which will
probably form the future campus.
During the summer and fall work
has been carried on in grading this
land, though its condition is now an
eyesore, owing to the work not being
complete. The "campus," in fact, has
been graded so as to form a bowl,
with a driveway around that part of
the "rim" which is not bordered by
Charles street. No arrangement has
as yet been made for properly draining this land. It is thought by many
that a slope gradually rising from the
street up to the half-circle of future
buildings would be more attractive.
The Carroll Mansion will form one
of the half-circle of buildings which
will probably extend around the rim
of the bowl above referred to. It does
not require an optimistic imagination
to picture with ease a university campus surrounded by stately buildings of
the Colonial style, similar in architecture to the Carroll Mansion.
The intended move of the Country School will be of interest to many
Hopkins Alumni. Among graduates
of the University who have taught
there at various times are: Roland J.
Mulford (headmaster), S. Wardwell
Kinney (headmaster), N. H. Ballard,
Arthur Lamb, J. Howard Post, William Starr Myers, Arthur Baxter,
Robert B. Roulston, Thomas De C.
Ruh, Samuel C. Chew, Robert Campbell, Walter Clark Haupt, and Herbert Cannon Lipscomb.
